PARAGRAPH.01: Making More Health (MMH) is a global initiative that aims to create a healthier world for individuals, communities and families.
PARAGRAPH.02: By supporting social entrepreneurs and social entrepreneurial thinking MMH will lead to innovative solutions and create social impact, help to find innovative business models and will also create a benefit for our own organizations and employees:
PARAGRAPH.03: It’s about creating Shared Value.

01.TITLE: What is a good goat house?

PARAGRAPH.01: A good goat house is:

01.010000: Dry
01.010100: On a slight slope (so that the urine can flow away)
01.020000: Raised floor
01.020300: With wooden floor so droppings and urine can fall down between boards (beware: openings should be small enough (<3cm) so goats do not stuck their legs between two boards)
01.030000: Big enough: approx. 2m x 2m x 2.5m for 10 goats
01.040000: The house can be less than 1 m higher than the soil, as long as you can remove the droppings by collection bags or clean them away manually.
01.050000: Can be wood or concrete and should be easy to wash
01.060000: Roof oriented East-West (not too hot at noon)
01.070000: Can be closed (cement or strong rice bags,…) if cold, too rainy or too windy
01.080000: Add to your goat house a water collection system from the roof to prepare for drought

01.TITLE: Add to your goat house a water collection system from the roof to prepare for drought.

02.TITLE: What is important to maintain good living conditions for goats?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats need hygiene. This means clean conditions:

01.010000: No mud
01.020000: Clean feed (hay rack)
01.030000: Remove droppings every day
01.040000: Wash your hands after checking the goat´s health
01.050000: Wash dirty surface with soap

01.TITLE: Remove droppings every day.

03.TITLE: Goat droppings: What to do with them?

01.010000: Diseases can be transmitted via droppings!
01.020000: Collect all droppings daily and place them in a compost heap
01.030000: Include organic left-overs (unspoiled) food
01.040000: You can stich rice bags together and make a flat basket. This basket could be used to collect the goat droppings (Refer to the figure).
01.050000: IMPORTANT to let droppings disintegrate for 6 months. This kills parasites and disease agents.
01.060000: Use the old droppings to fertilize your crops

01.TITLE: Collect all droppings daily and place them on a compost heap

04.TITLE: Do goats need to adapt to their new home?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats are very sensitive:

01.010000: Ask how goat was kept and fed before
01.020000: Provide or improve:
01.020200: The same time for pasture per day or more
01.020300: Provide as much water as they want
01.030000: If you buy other breed than Attappady or Malambary,
01.030300: and extra water in first week
01.040000: Check if new goats are in good health for one week, optimally 2 weeks before mixing the new goats with your goats.

01.TITLE: Check if new goats are in good health for one week, optimally 2 weeks before mixing the new goats with your goats.
How do I feed my goats well?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats can grow well only if they have enough feed:

01.010000: Let goats pasture.
01.020000: Do not feed goats with just rice or commercial feed concentrates! This avoids the disease acidosis (see Chapter 9.5)
01.030000: Every day, a goat needs 5 kg green (fresh plants) and 1 kg dry feed (your dried plants, or feed concentrate).
01.040000: Government provides feed to tribal people, so approach the nearest veterinary dispensary.
01.050000: Green feed:
01.050100: Leguminous plants have a lot of protein (like milk) and must be majority of feed: alfalfa, cespenia, mulberry… so ask for it.
01.060000: Dry plants: smaller part of feed.
01.070000: Dry feed: this must be the smaller part of feed (rice, local plants). Rice is not natural for goats and they quickly develop acidosis disease if too much rice is fed.
01.080000: Dry the fresh feed if needed later: hang feed on a rope to dry or build a rack out of bamboo.
01.090000: Feed must remain clean and dry: make a rack to hang the hay (less feed is wasted)

01.TITLE: Let goats pasture every day.

02.TITLE: Every day, a goat needs 5 kg green (fresh plants) and 1 kg dry feed (your dried plants, or feed concentrate).
Do goats need pasture?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats need good green feed to grow

01.010000: Yes, they need pasture!
01.020000: At least several hours each day.
01.030000: You can organize a herd within the village, and take turns to keep the goats.
01.040000: Take the opportunity of pasture to collect green feed, leaves, and bring it back to dry for drought time.
01.050000: Switch direction of pasture every month.
01.060000: Keep away from water streams with snails.
01.070000: More green feed is good: it helps growth and increases resistance to diseases and parasites.

01.TITLE: Switch direction of pasture every month.

03.TITLE: Feed farming: Do I need to cultivate crops?

PARAGRAPH.01: Growing your own crops always improves the feed and the goat health and growth

01.010000: Growing crops is important to have feed for drought time!
01.020000: Prepare for drought in the monsoon season. Collect fallen leaves and branches and let them dry. Goats love jackfruit leaves.
01.030000: Make a reserve of dried leaves, grass and hay
01.040000: Government provides seeds (to tribal people, so collect it)
01.050000: Good crops can be cut every 90 days
01.060000: Modern 'hybrid' grass (college grass) grows quicker (and therefore can be cut sooner) and is more nourishing
01.070000: Local traditional plants are also good because they are more resistant to bad weather conditions
01.080000: Grow crops from plants which live more than 2 years
01.090000: Corn provides a limited harvest, so grow only little corn and concentrate on other crops.

01.TITLE: Growing your own crops always improves the feed. Prepare for drought by collecting fallen leaves and branches.

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats need as much water as they can drink! This is very important for the body weight (and your sales price) and for the milk production!
PARAGRAPH.02: Without enough water,

01.010000: Provide water in the morning and in the evening
01.020000: Wait as long as they want to drink (do not take them away before they stop drinking)

02.010000: they do not grow (so you get less money when selling them)
02.020000: they give less milk

01.TITLE: Goats need as much water as they can drink!

02.TITLE: Provide clean water! Water is very important for the body weight (and your sales price) and for the milk production!

05.TITLE: Using eggs to improve health and survival of weak kids

PARAGRAPH.01: Construct a mobile chicken coop. You can move the coop to different areas. The advantages of the mobile chicken coop are (1) chicken droppings itself fertilizes different areas of your backyard (2) chickens can access and feed on the worms in the soil.

01.010000: If possible, build a 1 x 1 m cage using strong wooden sticks such as bamboo and raise 3 female chickens (refer to the figure). Firmly mount the cage to the ground so that it cannot be knocked down or moved by other animals.
01.020000: Chicken coops should be strong enough to afford protection against predators such as dogs, raptors etc.
01.030000: Chicken eggs are a good nutritious source for everyone especially children, pregnant women and elderly people. We need to understand that the chicken eggs are a good nutritious source of high-value protein for weak and rejected goat kids, too.
01.040000: Prepare a  soup with eggs, milk, cooked lentils and water by boiling it for at least 10 minutes. Feed the cooled down soup to malnourished goat kids several times a day, until it is healthy. Supplement the soup along with grass starting from two weeks of age.
01.050000: By four weeks of age, the goat kids might be able to feed by themselves.

01.TITLE: Prepare a soup with eggs, milk, cooked lentils and water by boiling it for at least 10 minutes. Feed to the kid when cooled down.

06.TITLE: How can I help my goats to provide sufficient milk?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats provided with plentiful water will produce more milk, so let the goat drink as much as it wants.

01.010000: Avoid udder diseases
01.010100: by keeping the goat house dry
01.010200: by keeping areas where the goats rest dry
01.020000: Give extra feed to skinny mother goats
01.020300: boiled eggs can be feed to weak goats

01.TITLE: Well hydrated goats produce more milk.
Which breed shall I use?

PARAGRAPH.01: Before you purchase goats, think and decide:

01.010000: Even healthy goats cannot do well if conditions are not good
01.010200: Keep feed quality, quantity and clean water in mind
01.010300: Prepare for good hygiene (=cleanliness level) and good housing
01.010400: Prepare for care (looking after animals every day)
01.020000: Native breed Attappady black is raised for meat production
01.020100: This breed is more resistant to drought
01.030000: Malabari breed is raised for milk and meat production less expensive than Attappady
01.030300: Produces a lot of milk (0.5-1.5kg/day). Average is 1 l/day.
01.030400: You can get 300 to 500 ml milk/day for human consumption.
01.030600: Needs more good quality feed – do you have this?
01.040000: Other imported breeds from different countries:

02.TITLE: Native breed Attappady black is raised for meat and generates income only after months of rearing through selling the grown kids.

04.TITLE: Malabari breed is a dairy breed and generates income during milking season.

02.TITLE: How do I find a good female and male goat to buy?

PARAGRAPH.01: Every year, you need to buy a new male to bring fresh blood into the goat family. Otherwise, diseases will occur.
PARAGRAPH.02: Check the female and the male goat at purchase for:
PARAGRAPH.03: You can share one male for the village. Change the male once per year.

01.010000: Good legs (female and male)
01.020000: Shiny fur (female and male)
01.030000: Check that the goat looks the age that the owner says (female and male). Target age to buy: 2- 3 years
01.030200: Adult: should have only adult teeth
01.030300: Too old adult: teeth are worn out already (over 5 years). If so, buy at a cheaper price.
01.040000: Well-placed udder with strong veins and large teats (female)

01.TITLE: Check the female and the male goat at purchase.

03.TITLE: Breeding book 'goat card': What do I need to write down?

PARAGRAPH.01: Writing down can help you:
PARAGRAPH.02: With a body weight of more than 2 kg at birth, kids reach the sales weight of 15 kg in 4 – 5 months. If they are smaller at birth, they need 7, 8 or 9 months to grow to the same sales weight.
PARAGRAPH.03: The sales price in 2019 is minimum 300 to 400 Rs/kg live weight. Do not sell at 100 Rs/kg.

01.010000: Identify each goat (different colours of collar, mark the ear,…) - less risk to be stolen
01.020000: Make a goat card:
01.020200: Mating date (if you keep the male separately)
01.020300: When the goat conceived the first (or second) time
01.020500: Number of kids per birth (average is 2)
01.020600: Body weight of kids at birth (good is more than 2 kg)
01.020900: Disease symptoms and date when seen

01.TITLE: Identify each goat by a tag and make a goat card for each goat.

02.TITLE: Make a goat card with all the important information and keep updated.

04.TITLE: How can I do good goat breeding?

PARAGRAPH.01: Males and females are both important:

01.010000: 1 male per maximum 10 females
01.020000: Every year: sell males and buy new ones from far away to avoid in-breeding
01.030000: Keep male and females separate
01.030100: Mating: look for signs of heat in the morning (female trying to mount other females, more aggressive, wagging its tail and bleating all the time) and bring together with male goat in the morning.
01.030200: Avoid using the same male for mating numerous times the same day. The conception likelihood will go down. If there are more female goats in heat, preferably use other male goat in the morning or a different male the following mating in the evening.
01.030300: Allow young females to mate only when ¾ of adult weight/size or 10kg weight reached, otherwise kids will grow poorly or likely die.
01.040000: If you keep male and females together all the time
01.040200: No need to check signs of heat as closely
01.040300: Is okay if goats are healthy
01.050000: Provide concentrate feed before mating to increase the number of kids and birth weight.

01.TITLE: Look for signs of heat in the morning.

02.TITLE: Allow young females to mate only when ¾ of adult size or 10 kg weight reached.

05.TITLE: Early pregnancy: What do I check during the early pregnancy?

PARAGRAPH.01: Pregnant goats need special attention and feeding:
PARAGRAPH.02: Early pregnancy:

01.010000: In the goat card, write down any of the below signs of pregnancy
01.010100: After approx. 3 weeks: does not go back in heat, belly tightens
01.010200: After 1.5 months: increased appetite, behavior changes
01.010300: After 3 months: increased belly, especially on the left
01.010400: If first pregnancy, udder is growing a bit after 1.5 months, well rounded around 3 months
01.020000: Goat pregnancy lasts 5 months (=150 days)
01.030000: With the goat card, plan the delivery date (week) and write it down
01.040000: Check weekly for signs of pregnancy (that the pregnancy continues well)

01.TITLE: In the goat card, write down any of the signs of pregnancy.

06.TITLE: Late pregnancy: What do I check at mid and late pregnancy?

PARAGRAPH.01: Pregnant goats need special attention and feeding!!!:
PARAGRAPH.02: Mid pregnancy:
PARAGRAPH.03: Late pregnancy:

01.010000: Check the goat card every week
01.020000: Hand-feed the kid so that it learns eating feed
01.030000: In the last 2 months before birth:
01.030100: Keep the older milk-suckling kid away

02.010000: Plan the delivery! – buy extra feed if you do not have enough crops growing at your farm or in community.
02.020000: Few days before delivery, goat eats and drinks less, just before birth, whitish secretion comes out from genital organ and from teats.
02.030000: Keep pregnant goat in separate and very clean and peaceful place and monitor every few hours before birth.

01.TITLE: In the last 2 months before birth, keep the older milk-suckling kid away and give the kid extra feed.

02.TITLE: Check the goat card every week to plan the delivery.

07.TITLE: Birth for the mother: How do I treat well the mother goat?

PARAGRAPH.01: Birth:
PARAGRAPH.02: Mother goat handling:

01.010000: Do not puncture the envelope around the first baby-kid when you start to see them (since it will affect the kid)
01.020000: Takes some hours (so do not pull out the kid in the first hour, it will hurt the animal and cause lesions and disease later)
01.030000: Call veterinarian if the kid has not come out after 4 hours of intense labor
01.040000: Afterbirth: comes out up to 12 hours later
01.050000: First milk is very important!
01.060000: If teats are blocked, milk manually

02.010000: Check that milk is taken in all days of first week
02.020000: Mother goat will have fluids discharged from the uterus for 2 - 4 weeks which start bloody and turn pale. IF NOT, very important to call veterinarian for antibiotics (since infection can kill mother and kid)

01.TITLE: Birth takes some hours, so do not pull the kid out in the first hour.

08.TITLE: Birth for the kid: How do I treat well the newborn kid?

01.010000: Kid handling:
01.010100: Umbilical cord: twist umbilical cord with both hands to allow the cord to close. Separate in the middle by pulling the cord apart but keeping no smaller than 10cm of closed cord on the kid (do not cut! Otherwise infections can kill the kid) and disinfect.
01.010200: Let mother goat clean up the newborn first. If this is not done by the mother goat, free nose of mucus and remove membranes by hand.
01.010300: If the newborn does not move, lift it by the hind legs and shake it in circles (to stimulate circulation and breathing).
01.010400: First milk is very important!!! (high protection against diseases and energy). Kid needs to drink within first 2 hours of life.
01.010500: Check that milk is taken in all days of first week.
01.020000: Check every day that mother accepts the kid.
01.030000: If kid is not accepted or kid does not drink within first 2 hours of life, milk mother manually and give milk feeding bottle, try to get acceptance in first day.
01.040000: For adopting: Bring the kid to another recent mother-goat, and wipe the kid with the new mother´s afterbirth to give it the same smell.

01.TITLE: Umbilical cord: twist and pull from both sides and disinfect.

09.TITLE: Twin birth: How do I treat well the twin kids and mother?

PARAGRAPH.01: Twin kid handling:

LIST.010000: If two kids are born, smear a bit of each kids afterbirth on the other one, so that both have the same smell.
LIST.020000: After this, place the first born to the mother´s head where the second (= last born) is.
LIST.030000: Help both kids to start drinking milk.
LIST.040000: Do not let other goats come close as they distract the mother.
LIST.050000: Keep all mother goats that have two newborns in a separate closed area for some days so they get used to each other.
LIST.060000: After this place both kids near the mothers head/face for her to accept both kids.

01.TITLE: If two kids are born, smear a bit of each kids afterbirth on the other one, so that both have the same smell.

10.TITLE: How to avoid that the mother rejects the kid?

PARAGRAPH.01: Rejection can be reduced by all this:

01.010000: Mating females only when adult (ie. not too early).
01.020000: Properly feeding the female goats used for breeding before bringing her to the billy goat (male).
01.030000: Feeding or allowing pasture of pregnant goat so that she can grow well.
01.040000: In case that two kids are born
01.040100: Do not let other goats come close and place the first born to the mother´s head (in the order they are born)
01.040200: Smear a bit of each kids afterbirth on the other one so that they both have the same smell.
01.040300: Keep each mother goat with two newborns in a separate closed area for some days (so that the three can get used to each other).

01.TITLE: In case that two kids are born, keep each mother goat with two newborns in a separate closed area for some days, so that the three can get used to each other.

11.TITLE: What to do with kids rejected by the mother goat?

PARAGRAPH.01: If kept alone, the kids suffer a lot! So, give the rejected kids feed and special care. Otherwise, they will become sick and die.

01.010000: All these will help to save the kids´ lives:
01.010100: Feed cooked eggs in small pieces, mixed with milk for two weeks daily. This will make them strong.
01.010200: Feed cow milk diluted with boiled water. Raw water will make the kid sick.
01.010201: Give boiled water (at lukewarm heat) in a feeding bottle. Feed for at least 10 minutes with a very small hole.Keep an eye on the size of the nipple hole to prevent the kid from suckling too quickly and choke.
01.010301: Crush unsalted milk biscuits or cereals
01.010400: Feed lentils or other protein-rich plants.

01.TITLE: If left alone, the kids suffer a lot! So, give the rejected kids feed and special care.

12.TITLE: Goat childhood: How do I do good kid kindergarten?

PARAGRAPH.01: Like handling of our children! Taking care of the small kids helps the adults and brings a bright future.

01.010000: First milk is very important!
01.020000: From the first days of life onwards, kids need access to green raw feed! (this is important to develop good digestion and growth later)
01.030000: Let them go to pasture together with the mother all the time
01.040000: Separate kids from mother only when she is pregnant again
01.050000: No milk-suckling kid in the last 2 months before giving birth if the kid is at least 3 months old and growing well

01.TITLE: Do good goat kid kindergarten: First milk is very important. From the mother goat or via hand-feeding of rejected kids.
How can I earn more money with goats?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats can help you generate income, but they can also cost money. For this, you need to understand the basic economic principles:

01.010000: Initial investment of money: how much do I need?
01.020000: Making money: only by selling a goat
01.020100: All your efforts must focus on getting several kids and keeping kids and goats alive and well to achieve 15 kg sales weight in 5 months
01.020200: Possibly, you can also sell the droppings. Find out whether people are interested.
01.030000: Find out purchase prices
01.030200: For young and for adult: minimum 300 to 400 Rs/ kg live weight
01.040000: Find out sales prices
01.040100: Are they different than purchase price?
01.050000: Save over a time, together in the self-help group
01.060000: Plan whether you want the complete money back in a year or have income when you need it.
01.070000: Goat card helps to know the money status: when can you expect how much money to earn and to spend

01.TITLE: Goat card helps you plan your finances from goat rearing: when can you expect how much money to earn and to spend.

02.TITLE: What is organic farming?

PARAGRAPH.01: Feeding and raising goats for meat or milk production can be done in different ways. (The same principle applies for cow milk and meat, for chicken eggs and vegetables.) There are two major ways:
PARAGRAPH.02: 1. The industrialized way, which means
PARAGRAPH.03: 2. The organic way, which means
PARAGRAPH.04: In order to receive a higher price for 'organic' products, the production must be officially certified. This means
PARAGRAPH.05: There are differently strict standards, depending on how much modern chemicals can be used. This refers to the modern chemical medicines because they are very effective for treatment of diseases.

01.010000: Modern production with chemical fertilizers, pesticides or hormones to maximize production.
01.020000: This usually saves some work and increases the output, but special care must be taken to follow all application rules, since otherwise, it is less healthy for the environment (kills bees, butterflies) and can affect the health of people who work with it.
01.030000: Unless all application rules are followed, it can also leave residues on or in the product, hence the product will be less healthy when you eat it.

02.010000: Without chemical fertilizers, pesticides or hormones, equivalent to a very natural and healthy production.
02.020000: In other words, it is the traditional way where diseases are cured with local plants and natural medicine (ayurvedic or other tribal medicine) and prudent use of modern medicine.
02.030000: This production is more labour-intensive and less productive, but healthier, so the products must and does get a higher price.

03.010000: An inspection of the practice by government authorities, checking all production steps and how production is organized.
03.020000: In India, certification is issued by testing centres accredited (this means checked and approved) by the Agricultural and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority (APEDA), under the National Program for Organic Production of the Government of India.

01.TITLE: The traditional and tribal way can produce healthy high quality meat. Engage with others to make use of this as organic food.

02.TITLE: Example of an Indian organic product.

03.TITLE: Organic farming is a growing business. If you are interested, search for partners and organic cooperative options.
How can you create a profitable business around goats?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats can bring you more money indirectly. Find out what practices are done in your neighboring villages and what could work. Here are different ideas. You may offer a service business around goats in the villages of your area:

01.010000: Can you create 'kid adoption' business? For those kids which people have not taken care. Taking care takes time, so you can offer this service.
01.020000: Or can you create 'pasture' business? If people have no time to pasture or the good grass is far away.
01.030000: Or can you create 'leaves collection' or 'hay-making' business? If people have no time to pasture or have not prepared for drought. You could sell the dried leaves and hay in used rice bags.
01.040000: Or can you create business by offering jackfruit leaves and plant trees in your village? Goats like the taste of jackfruit leaves and you can offer this to good goat keepers to increase milk production even more.
01.050000: Sell goat droppings and/or use it as a fertilizer once composted. You could grow mushrooms on the compost heap and sell them.

01.TITLE: Here are different ideas. You may offer a service business around goats in the villages of your area.

04.TITLE: What is most important for generating more income with goats?

01.010000: Thin goats can easily catch diseases
01.010100: Feed well all goats and especially kids
01.010200: Do not accept that some goats or kids look thinner
01.010300: Give them as much clean water as they want
01.010400: Pasture your goats as much as possible
01.010500: Change places for every month, wherever possible
01.020000: Collect the droppings daily and put them on the compost pile
01.030000: Remove ticks every day
01.030100: Collect in a container and burn or crush them
01.030200: Family members like children can help
01.040000: Keep goats on dry, clean soil
01.050000: Isolate ill goats and new animals (for one, better 2 weeks)

01.TITLE: Always keep good track of your goats.

05.TITLE: Raising goats in a humane and compassionate manner

01.010000: Goats and other animals are just like people should to be treated well.
01.020000: Express what you want with your voice.
01.030000: If the goat does do what you want it to do, speak shortly and directly to her. Look at the goat and gesture with your hands to signal what you want it to do.
01.040000: Speak loud and clearly.
01.050000: Beating and abusing goats is never good!
01.060000: If you want to speed up your goat,dog,a cow, verbally signal them just as you would with a person. Then, the animal or the person will understand well.
01.060100: Never hit or beat an animal.
01.060200: You will live more in peace and your animals will be healthier, overall, because they are happy and they trust you.

01.TITLE: Goats and other animals are like people and like to be treated well. Speak loud and clearly. Look at the goat and gesture with your hands to signal what you want it to do.
Main characteristics of goats?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goats are very important for people, and they are a bit similar to humans. However, did you know that there are differences?
PARAGRAPH.02: What goats share with humans:
PARAGRAPH.03: However, goats are different from humans:

01.010000: We all have an average body temperature within a certain range
01.020000: We need clean water
01.030000: We need to walk
01.040000: Females need to be adult when before giving birth to their first goat kid or human baby
01.050000: Our newborns first drink milk
01.060000: You can count the age on the teeth

02.010000: The body temperature is higher: Human 36.5°C – 37.5°C / Goats 38.5°C – 40.5°C
02.020000: Goats have 4 stomachs (and humans only 1)
02.030000: Hence, goats must eat differently. Rice alone is not good. Goats must have rich fibres in their diet.
02.040000: Goats can have more digestion problems than humans
02.050000: Goat pregnancy lasts 5 months compared to 9 for humans
02.060000: The goat does not transfer protection factors against diseases to its kids during pregnancy (in contrast to women and babies), but only with first milk.
02.070000: Newborns must consume the first milk from their mother quickly during the first days (otherwise there is risk of illnesses and death).
02.080000: Having twins is common in goats, so feeding the mother goat well during pregnancy is especially important.

01.TITLE: The body temperature of goats is higher than for humans.

02.TITLE: What can cause diseases?

PARAGRAPH.PARAGRAPH_01: The body can get ill in many ways. This is the same for goats as for other animals and for people. Diseases can start small – for example as a weakness - and increase, if they are not recognized and controlled early.
PARAGRAPH.03: These are the disease agents:

01.010000: The environment, such as:
01.010200: Dirty water or not enough water
01.010402: Too many goats on the same place
01.020000: Poisoning, such as:
01.020204: Drugs for cows if the dose is not adjusted to goats
01.030000: The heredity of the goat family:
01.040000: The disease agents: micro-organisms (cannot be seen by eye) and parasites

02.010000: Some stay in or on goats only, some pass on to humans and other animals
02.020000: Some are transmitted by mosquitoes, ticks, snails, whereas some pass on directly
02.010000: Bacteria
02.010100: Too small to seen by eye, but bacteria can grow to be seen by eye (white or yellow dots)
02.010200: Grow inside and outside the body
02.010300: Cause diseases like Brucellosis, Tuberculosis and Salmonellosis
02.010400: Can survive in nasal discharge, droppings, dirty water/muddy floor
02.020000: Viruses
02.020100: Too small to seen by eye, only grow only inside the body
02.020200: In goats: PPR (disease like goat plague) and FMD (foot and mouth disease), ...
02.020300: In humans: influenza, HIV/ AIDS, Dengue and Chikungunya. Can survive in discharges and environment to contaminate other animals
02.030300: Starts small, but can grow to be seen by eye, can smell bad
02.040000: Parasites: like a small animal living on or in bigger animal and causing harm. Many types:
02.040100: Fleas: Can spread between all animals and humans
02.040200: Lice: Do not spread a lot between human and goats
02.040300: Ticks: Should be removed every day because ticks can transmit diseases in one day
02.040400: Larvae of flies (the worms which develop into flies): in the stomach
02.040600: Fluke: inside in liver and lungs
02.040700: Worms: Can live in skin, lungs, intestine, liver, even in brain

03.TITLE: How to distinguish a sick goat from a healthy goat?

PARAGRAPH.02: Healthy goat:
PARAGRAPH.03: Sick goat:
PARAGRAPH.04: Very important:

01.010000: Bright, calm, pays attention to its environment
01.020000: Goat that stays with other goats
01.030000: Strong
01.040000: Normal walking (not 'tired')
01.050000: Good appetite, eats and chews feed
01.060000: Soft and smooth skin, shiny hair
01.080000: Pink and moist mouth, vulva and nostrils

02.010000: Depressed, nervous and restless
02.020000: Goat which does not stay with other goats
02.070100: You can also see dirty lines at the height of goats: search for external parasites
02.070200: Is not normal! Skin parasites are usually behind it!
02.090000: Rough skin, bare in some places
02.100000: Lack of appetite or eats soil or droppings or does not drink enough water
02.130000: Red, dark or pale, purple or dry mouth and vulva or cracked nostrils
02.150000: Discharge from nose, mouth, eyes, ears or genital organs

03.010000: Any of these signs alone already shows that the goat is sick.
03.020000: The signs can be the same for adult goats and for kids.
03.030000: So, isolate the goat from the rest of the herd and treat it quickly.
03.040000: Do not wait until the goat gets more disease signs or the disease spreads to others.

05.TITLE: Which Goat Diseases Can Be Transmitted To Humans?

PARAGRAPH.01: Many diseases can be transmitted from goats to humans! Therefore, keep all your goats healthy, so that your children and you can stay healthy.
PARAGRAPH.02: Sometimes, humans get the same symptoms as goats, sometimes not.
PARAGRAPH.03: Therefore, always wash your hands carefully before and after checking sick goats. In addition, isolate them and do not let children approach them.
PARAGRAPH.04: Pregnant women should always be careful when taking care of goats, and avoid goats in case of goat abortion. These diseases can cause abortion and illness to the woman!
PARAGRAPH.05: Goats can also infect cows or sheeps and vice versa! So, keep healthy and sick animals apart. And if possible, keep goats apart from cows or sheep.

01.010000: External parasites (ticks, fleas, mites): they cause skin problems and they can also transmit diseases to humans and goats
01.020000: Rabies: deadly for humans and goats
01.030000: Brucellosis: infertility and abortions for humans and goats
01.040000: Diarrhea (worms, bacteria or virus): mostly same disease for humans and goats
01.050000: Echinococcosis (worm): a worm growing mainly in liver of humans and goats, but lungs and brain can also get infected. It can be  a deadly disease.

07.TITLE: How do you clean the wounds on your goat?

PARAGRAPH.01: Deep wounds have to be cleaned and disinfected to avoid more disease. How to do this?

01.010000: If wound is fresh and the goat allows it, press around it so that blood flushes out dirt.
01.020000: Remove all dirty and dead tissues with soapy water.
01.030000: Drain with a syringe filled with disinfectant oxygenated water (also called hydrogen peroxide) (it will create foam, which is good to remove dirt) or iodine diluted with clean water.
01.040000: Let disinfectant flow out of the wound with the dirt.
01.050000: Monitor wound every day and repeat cleaning.

PARAGRAPH.01: Fever is the first sign of many diseases from bacteria and viruses. Use a thermometer to measure the temperature.
PARAGRAPH.02: Normal goat temperature: between 38.5°C and 40.5°C.
PARAGRAPH.03: If the goats’ body temperature is above 40.5°C: it means the animal has fever. If the it is also a cause for concern if the goats body temperature falls below 38.5°C.
PARAGRAPH.04: Use a thermometer as follows:

01.010000: Shake the thermometer so that the temperature indicated is very low. Cool it with water from the shade if air temperature is near 40°C.
01.020000: Someone holds the goat if possible
01.030000: Push the thermometer into the anus, maximum to a third of it, and make it touch the side of the intestine
01.040000: Wait at least one minute
01.050000: Take it out and read it
01.060000: Clean with soapy water and store it far from heat or hot sun, in the shade in your house

This means to destroy the disease agents with medications and to help the goat fight the disease. Vaccination will not work any more as the goat is already sick.
PARAGRAPH.02: There are allopathic medications and ayurvedic medicine based on plants. allopathic medicine is usually very effective and quick, while ayurvedic or plant based medicine can be supportive. The use of each depends on the setting.

01.030000: They are not expired.
01.040000: They are used with the recommended administration route (antibiotics are usually injected intramuscularly (= i.m. is usually written on the drug bottle).
01.050000: They are used for the time period recommended by the veterinarian (not even one day less!). For example, some antibiotics have to be injected several times to  work. This usually happens with the cheaper antibiotic because it is the least concentrated. Ask the veterinarian to do the injection.

What should you do before treating or applying medications to your goats?

PARAGRAPH.01: Before applying any treatment, weigh your goat, using a scale.
PARAGRAPH.02: This does not apply for vaccination since all vaccines are automatically made in the form of 1 dose per animal (for both  goat kids or adults ).
PARAGRAPH.03: You need to know that:
PARAGRAPH.04: Remember not to eat a goat just after treatment. Your veterinarian will tell you how many days you have to wait after treatment before eating it.

01.010000: It will allow you to determine the proper dosage (number of ml to apply).
01.020000: dosage is based on the weight of the goat and advised “per kilo”.
01.030000: The correct dose will give your goat a better chance to recover from the disease.
01.040000: If you cannot weight or do not know the weight, ask your veterinarian how much medicine you should give.

02.010000: Over-dosage is dangerous for the health of your goat (similar to plant pesticides used wrongly for tick removal).
02.020000: Under-dosage can create resistance, meaning that the disease agent or parasite gets used to the medicine and still lives and damages the goat.
02.020100: This is very dangerous, since the disease or parasite then spreads in the herd and the village.
02.020101: So, never use too little dose of medicine.

03.TITLE: Dangerous for goats: What is Goat POX?

PARAGRAPH.01: Goat Pox is a disease caused by a virus. Goat pox is a skin disease showing many raised spots on the skin of the goats.
PARAGRAPH.02: Goats with goat pox can only infect other goats, not other animals.

01.010000: How do goats get it?
01.020000: Skin sores and saliva are transmitting the virus.
01.030000: Skin scabs can be infectious for a long time.
01.040000: Other animals contacting the scabs will get sick.

02.010000: Usually, most of the goats show the disease.
02.020000: Some animals will die.
02.030000: The severity of goat pox depends on other factors such as parasites, nutrition, and weather.
02.040000: Goat pox is common in summer.
02.050000: So, treat your goats against parasites to keep the strong and to avoid getting infected and spreading the goat pox virus.
02.060000: There is no treatment. Isolate ill animals.

04.TITLE: Dangerous for goats and people: What is Echinococcosis?

PARAGRAPH.01: Echinococcosis is a disease caused by a worm parasite called 'Echinococcus'. There are worms which live in the liver, lungs and brain of goats! They have a complicated name, and they cause a complicated disease which can lead to death. The worm growns like cancer in the body.
PARAGRAPH.02: If goats have this and the brain, lung or the liver is eaten, then the disease spreads to the dog or the human who eat it.
PARAGRAPH.03: Hence, it is important to:
PARAGRAPH.04: When eating goat meat (or any other animal meat), always cook it well to kill the parasites (at least 30 min!).
PARAGRAPH.05: Always take care when handling soil, dirt or animal hair because it may contain parasite eggs. The same applies to fruits and berries and vegetables: wash them before eating them.

01.010000: Keep new goats separate from the rest of the herd for at least one week or better yet for 2 weeks!
01.020000: Give an antiparasitic treatment when the new goats arrive

02.010000: Important recommendation for slaughter: keep dogs away!
02.020000: Do not let dogs eat un-cooked inner organs. By this, echinococcus disease worm (and other diseases) can be passed on.

05.TITLE: Dangerous for goats and people: What is Rabies?

PARAGRAPH.01: Rabies is a disease caused by a virus.
PARAGRAPH.02: There is pre and post exposure vaccination available against rabies.
PARAGRAPH.03: How do animals and people get rabies?
PARAGRAPH.04: How does rabies look like?

01.010000: All mammals/milk-giving animals including goats can get it.
01.020000: Birds do NOT get it.
01.030000: Once infected, there is a very highly chance of death for animal or person.
01.040000: For people, goats and cows, there is after-bite medicine to be injected as soon as possible to prevent the virus from spreading to the brain/CNS. If given to the goat 30 min after the bite, and depending on close  the bite is away from head, it can save the goat.

02.010000: Ask whether you should vaccinate your dogs to prevent getting and spreading rabies.
02.020000: Ask your human doctor whether you yourself should get vaccination against rabies.

03.010000: By a bite of an infected animal, usually a dog.
03.020000: Also, contact of saliva or blood with a skin wound or mouth, nose, genital organs will transmit the disease.

04.010000: People can become scared of water.
04.020000: Carnivores like dogs usually get angry.
04.030000: Herbivores like goats usually get quiet.
04.040000: The goat with rabies will loose energy. It will not pasture. It may fall down and not move anymore.
04.050000: If you observed this, and in particular if you know the goat has been bitten, call the veterinarian immediately and do not touch the goat anymore. Close off the area so that the infected goat does not come in contact with humans or other animals.

01.TITLE: Animals and people get rabies usually by a bite of an infected animal, mostly a dog.

01.020000: Leaches: can live on skin, but also inside in liver
01.030000: Larvae of flies (the worms which develop into flies)
01.040000: Blood parasites (very small and live in blood cells)
01.040100: Trypanosoma, Babesia (all in goats), Malaria (in humans)...

02.010000: Many parasites multiply via eggs which can be found in dung.
02.020000: Out of these eggs, small larvae (like mini-worms) hatch out of the eggs.
02.030100: either in the grass where the larvae look for the next host
02.030200: or already inside the next host animal.
02.040000: Some parasites first live in snails, for example, before they go into goats and other animals.

03.040000: Cutting grass from riverside in rainy season and let dry for 2 months.
03.050000: All this will help because: Worm parasite eggs usually need some weeks to mature and become adult.

04.010000: Whenever the goat has parasites, the goat grows slowly and poorly and you need to provide more feed.
04.020000: Also, if the goat is weak it can catches other diseases more easily.
04.030000: The goat needs to be treated as soon as possible. Call your veterinarian!
04.040000: The de-worming schedule depends on the topographical location.
04.050000: The good thing is that there is medicine to treat the many different internal and external parasites altogether. Ask your veterinarian.

05.010000: If not, there is the risk that parasites become resistant to the medicine.
05.020000: Therefore, the type of allopathic medicine and its chemically active substance needs to be changed periodically. This is called 'de-worming schedule'.
05.030000: A dung samples analysis can tell which and how many parasites the goat flock has.

PARAGRAPH.01: Bronchitis is the disease of the airways which go deep into the lung. Sniffling or discharge from the nose seems harmless, but can develop into bronchitis.
PARAGRAPH.02: Bronchitis is a more severe form of respiratory disease. The goat needs weeks to recover. During this recovery time, it grows slowly and and readily contract  other diseases.
PARAGRAPH.03: Bronchitis can be caused
PARAGRAPH.04: Bronchitis can have the following signs:

01.030000: by viruses,

02.010000: Coughing
02.020000: Breathing difficulties
02.040000: Goat is slower than normal and without energy

03.010000: Isolate the sick goat as it can spread the disease to healthy goats.

04.TITLE: What Is Enteritis = The Disease Causing Diarrhea?

PARAGRAPH.01: Enteritis is the disease of the intestines (gut inflammation)  which causes diarrhea. A change in colour or consistency of the droppings seems harmless, but can develop into diarrhea.
PARAGRAPH.02: Enteritis is more severe. The goat needs weeks to recover. During recovery, it grows slowly and can get other diseases more easily.
PARAGRAPH.03: Diseases can be caused
PARAGRAPH.04: Enteritis can have the following signs:
PARAGRAPH.06: Avoid transmission from the goat: What to do if you observe any of these signs at a goat:
PARAGRAPH.07: It is possible that goats transmit enteritis to humans. So take care while performing  cleaning and washing recommendations as described in chapter 5.5 of this manual.

01.010000: by parasites
01.020000: by bacteria
01.030000: by viruses,

02.010000: Liquid droppings
02.020000: Bloody droppings
02.040000: Swollen and hard belly (but goat is not pregnant, if female)
02.050000: Walking without energy and keeping the back tight because of belly pain

03.010000: The goats can loose a lot of water from their digestive system and even from the blood circulation. This critical loss of water is called 'dehydration'.
03.020000: Dehydration can happen really quickly, especially if the goats are young.
03.030000: They can die in within a few hours!

04.010000: Isolate the sick goat since the disease can spread.
04.020000: Lift a piece of skin between two fingers to about  2 inches, as in the respective chapter 5.5 of this manual and let go. The skin should go back to its original state quickly.. If it remains standing up, there is critical loss of water (ie dehydration).
04.040000: Call the veterinarian and tell the temperature.
04.050000: The goat should be treated as soon as possible.
04.060000: There are many different parasites which all can cause diarrhea.
04.070000: The veterinarian can also help you to prevent other goats falling ill with the same disease.
04.080000: If the veterinarian recommends to treat all animals, please do so immediately. The other goats may look healthy but can be infected with the parasite without showing, visible diarrhea or clinical signs.

05.010000: Remove droppings and clean secretions of sick goats with water and soap
05.020000: Disinfect the soil where the sick goat was housed
05.030000: If the goat dies, bury or burn the carcass and disinfect the soil
05.040000: A SICK GOAT MUST NOT BE EATEN!

PARAGRAPH.01: Acidosis is the disease of the second (called rumen), of the four stomachs, which goats have. It is a digestion disorder.
PARAGRAPH.02: This means, that acidosis is fundamentally different from the transmittable diseases mentioned before . It is mostly a man-made disease that is a result of poor feeding!
PARAGRAPH.03: In the healthy second stomach, there are many good bacteria and other single-cell micro-organisms.
PARAGRAPH.04: Acidosis literally means that the liquid of the stomach gets too acidic.
PARAGRAPH.06: Acidosis can have the following signs:
PARAGRAPH.07: What to do if you observe any of these signs at a goat?
PARAGRAPH.08: The goat will take several weeks to recover. During recovery, it grows slowly and can acquire other diseases, especially enteritis, more easily.
PARAGRAPH.09: It is NOT possible that goats transmit acidosis to humans because this is a disorder caused by poor feeding and not an infectious agent or parasite.
PARAGRAPH.10: Humans do not have a second stomach. However, eating poorly can also cause short- and long-term health problems in humans.

01.010000: It is actually these micro-organisms which eat the green feed and the dry feed so that they can be digested by the goat.
01.020000: Without these beneficial micro-organisms, the goat could not derive nutrition from its feed!

02.010000: Because of this, the  beneficial micro-organisms in the stomach are weakened, reduced in number or killed.
02.020000: There are also harmful micro-organisms in the stomach and they now grow in numbers.
02.030000: The goat suffers when the harmful microbes grow and the beneficial microbes start to die.

03.010000: By poor feeding!, so essentially, the owner is giving too much of incorrect feed, for example:
03.010100: Rice (it must not be more than a quarter of daily feed)
03.020000: Acidosis can also be the results of poisoning with chemicals or
03.030000: By bacteria which also disturb the balance of second stomach.

04.010000: The goat does not eat normally any more
04.020000: Swollen and hard belly (but is not pregnant, if female)
04.030000: Goat shows signs of stomach ache

05.010000: Isolate the sick goat since you do not know whether it is acidosis or an infectious/contagious disease.
05.030000: Call the veterinarian and tell the temperature.
05.040000: The goat should be treated as soon as possible.
05.050000: Change what you feed the goat: Reduce the rice in feed! Let goats pasture and give them plenty of hay.

01.TITLE: Very important: acidosis is caused by poor feeding

02.TITLE: Goats need green feed and hay for their good health!

PARAGRAPH.01: Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause disease in muscles, heart, brain and nerves. Deficiency means the lack of an essential nutrient (a substance or component in food and feed) which is called vitamin B1 or 'thiamine'.
PARAGRAPH.02: 'Vitamin' is a general term for all those substances which goats (and humans) need to eat, because the body cannot make them by himself. Therefore, vitamin B1 deficiency can only happen when the goat (and humans) does not eat properly or get good feed.
PARAGRAPH.03: In goats, vitamin B1 deficiency can also be a digestion disorder coming from problems in the second stomach, the rumen (see chapter 9.5). In a healthy goat, the beneficial microorganisms in the second stomach produce vitamin B1 and thus nourish the goat. When this second stomach gets gets affected, harmful microorganisms grow and cause many problems including vitamin B1 deficiency.
PARAGRAPH.04: This means, that vitamin B1 deficiency is fundamentally different from transmittable diseases  mentioned earlier . It is mostly a man-made disease resulting from  feeding the animals poorly!
PARAGRAPH.05: Very important: vitamin B1 deficiency is caused
PARAGRAPH.06: Vitamin B1 deficiency can have the following signs:
PARAGRAPH.07: What to do if you observe any of these signs at a goat?
PARAGRAPH.08: There are many more vitamins than B1. Goats also need all the other vitamins. Hence, with good nutritious feed and good pasture, one can prevent many vitamin deficiencies and other diseases altogether!
PARAGRAPH.09: It is NOT possible for goats transmit vitamin B1 deficiency to humans because this is a disorder that was caused by poor feed.
PARAGRAPH.10: Humans do not have a second stomach. However, bad eating habits and nutritionally poor food can cause short- and long-term problems including vitamin B1 deficiency in humans.

01.010000: Goat kids are very sensitive to vitamin B1 deficiency.
01.020000: The longer the goat is on a poor diet, the greater the vitamin deficiency and consequent suffering for the goat.

02.010000: By poor feed!, so essentially, the owner is giving too much of improper feed:
02.010100: Rice (it must not be more than a quarter of daily feed)
02.020000: Vitamin B1 deficiency can also be the result of chemical poisoning or
02.030000: By harmful bacteria which disturb the balance of second stomach.

03.010000: Weak hind legs or goat can raise front legs, but not hind legs
03.030000: Blindness and other eye problems like flickering from one side to the other.

04.010000: Isolate the sick goat since you do not know whether it is vitamin B1 deficiency or an infectious or contagious disease.
04.030000: Call the veterinarian and tell the temperature.
04.040000: The goats should be treated as soon as possible. The veterinarian can inject vitamin B1. The goat needs a day to recover. However, if the muscles, heart, brain or nerves are damaged too much, they may not fully recover!
04.050000: Change what you feed your goats. Reduce the amount of rice included in the feed! Let goats pasture and give plenty of hay.

01.TITLE: Very important: Vitamin B1 deficiency is caused by poor feed.

01.TITLE: If your goat gets skin problems, what can it be?

PARAGRAPH.01: Some signs are common to different diseases. If your goat shows skin problems, it can be one of these common reasons:
PARAGRAPH.02: There are many more diseases caused by bacteria.
PARAGRAPH.03: Examine your goat by daily health check. It  is important to inform the veterinarian about all the signs which you have observed in the whole body. These will help you to find the disease and the correct treatment and prevention.

01.010000: Mange (scabies = disease by external parasites, namely: mites): intense itching!, skin is thickened, rough and crackled, loss of hair.
01.020000: Goat pox: many raised spots, mainly in summer.
01.030000: Fungal disease: looks like circular marks, pale, thick, without hair, no itching.
01.030100: Treatment: Iodine or anti-fungal medication containing 'ketoconazole'
01.040000: Sunburn: only on white parts, the skin gets red and crackled.
01.040100: Treatment: avoid exposure to midday sunlight, if a goat is very sensitive, do not use for breeding

01.TITLE: Different diseases can show up at the skin. Daily health check helps to find the disease and the correct treatment and prevention.

02.TITLE: If your goat does not grow well, what can it be?

PARAGRAPH.01: Some signs are common to different diseases. If your goat doesn’t grow well, it can be one of these common reasons:
PARAGRAPH.02: There are many more diseases, also from bacteria.
PARAGRAPH.03: Examine your goat by daily health check. It is important to inform the veterinarian about all the signs which you have observed in the whole body. These will help you to identify the disease and determine the correct treatment and prevention.

01.010000: Internal worm parasites: can show yellowish eyes, pale inside mouth and eyelid, normal appetite, bad breath, swollen belly, diarrhea.
01.010100: Treatment: antiparasitic medications from your veterinarian, including 'de-worming schedule' and dung sample analysis.
01.020000: Internal blood parasites: can show yellowish eyes, pale inside mouth and eyelid, normal belly, weak.
01.020100: Treatment: antiparasitic medicine from your veterinarian.
01.030000: Acidosis: reduced appetite, swollen and hard belly, belly ache, diarrhoea.
01.030100: Treatment: good feeding. Apply recommendations from chapter 3.
01.040000: Bad feeding and little water provision: upon pulling, skin does not go down immediately, bones and hips can be felt easily through the fur.
01.040100: Treatment: good feeding and watering. Apply the recommendations from chapter 3.

03.TITLE: If your goat is limping, what can it be?

PARAGRAPH.01: Some signs are common to different diseases. If your goat is limping, it can be one of these four common reasons:
PARAGRAPH.02: There are many more diseases, also from bacteria; and fractures and snake bites. Mostly, bacteria start from a wound which goes deep.
PARAGRAPH.03: Daily health check for the whole body, cleaning and disinfection of wounds is very important.

01.010000: Foot-and-mouth-disease (FMD): blisters in mouth, feet and teats.
01.010100: Treatment: alert veterinarian since this disease is controlled by the government, wound cleaning and disinfection
01.020000: Joint inflammation: warm, swollen and painful; can be brucellosis or other bacterial disease
01.030000: Blackleg disease: caused by bacteria, hesitating to walk, swollen muscle, air pocket under the skin when touched; dry skin
01.030100: Treatment: urgency! veterinarian can give antibiotics, wound cleaning, goat will die if not treated immediately. The carcass will have stiff legs. Do not open it! as the bacteria can be transmitted to humans readily and can lead to death in the human!
01.040000: Foot rot disease: caused by bacteria, wound between claws, no vesicles in the mouth or on the teat
01.040100: Treatment: veterinarian can give antibiotics, wound cleaning

01.TITLE: Different diseases can show up as limping. Daily health check helps to identify the disease and determine the correct treatment and prevention.

04.TITLE: If your goat suddenly dies, what can it be?

PARAGRAPH.01: Some signs are common to different diseases. If your goat is limping, it can be one of these four common reasons:
PARAGRAPH.02: Call the veterinarian for further instructions. Do not leave the animal in the field or in contact with other animals. Put gloves when transporting it to another place and wash your hands well with soap and water after transporting animals.
PARAGRAPH.03: If no veterinarian is available to examine the dead goat: bury deeply with quicklime. This destroys the dangerous bacteria.

01.010000: Bacterial poisoning of intestine, called 'Enterotoxaemia': very severe disease. Either sudden death, or swollen belly with  bloody diarrhea.
01.010100: Prevention: prophylactic/preventive vaccine. Never change feeding abruptly!
01.020000: PPR: Discharge, Diarrhea, Death
01.030000: Generalised bleeding disease, called 'Pasteurellosis': swollen head, neck, throat, noisy breathing, dry cough, purulent discharge from nose and mouth, bloody diarrhea
01.040000: Anthrax : purple membranes of mouth and eyelid with blood spots, diarrhea, after death soft legs of the carcass. Do not open the carcass! Do not eat the meat! Anthrax can lead to human death!

01.TITLE: Different diseases can lead to sudden death. Alert the veterinarian. Bury the carcass with quicklime and do not eat! Some diseases are dangerous for people, too.
